stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream polishing new star-select screens and related course assets instead of the planned Ol’ Block boss. He collaborates live with artist Biobak on lights, clouds, a bobbing submarine and an animated bird, while also troubleshooting a sine-wave bug, discussing future level themes and mentioning an upcoming house move.

development_findings.summary: Ol’ Block boss is functionally complete; remaining tasks are grill animations and difficulty balancing via extra coins and moving platforms.
development_findings.quote: I think all that's missing right now for the boss fight is the grills animating.

development_findings.summary: Cut-scene plan: Ol’ Block swallows Mario, fades in from purple, shows caged prisoners, then spits Mario to the opposite side of the arena. Kaze agrees to add the spit-out animation.
development_findings.quote: Maybe after he comes out of here we just have an animation of him spitting out Mario and Mario lands on the opposite end.

development_findings.summary: Submarine bobbing used sine waves but produced wild values because math.h wasn’t included; GCC linked garbage data. Adding the header and switching to a custom sine table fixed the motion.
development_findings.quote: How can a sine wave do that? It’s not what sine waves do.

development_findings.summary: Vertex-colored light cones on the water course were banding and showed an “X”; Kaze fixed it by separating the overlapping circles, blurring the texture and using texture whiteness as an alpha channel.
Replaced placeholder submarine with a higher-poly model; level still holds 60 FPS on real N64, allowing more ambience like fish and jellyfish.
development_findings.quote: The level that the sub is in runs 60 FPS on N64 pretty much consistently. We can actually go sicko mode on that level.

development_findings.summary: Star-select bird: idle twitch animation and take-off coded; discovery that engine stops object updates during fade-out means a new logic path is needed.
development_findings.quote: Everything just freezes when I press A; I need the bird to update.

development_findings.summary: Clouds on Lofty Lumber Leaves now bob vertically using sine waves and a hex-tessellated plane despite initial hesitation from Biobak.
Entire overworld will be redesigned as a single tropical island inspired by a Mario Party board; current teleports will be removed.
development_findings.quote: The entire overworld will be reworked, so nothing you see in the overworld is going to be the same.

development_findings.summary: Retro sections currently planned: Paper Mario 64 Goomba Town, Mario Paint, Dr. Mario, Mario Land 1, Smash 64; Kaze is open to swapping them.
development_findings.quote: We looked at all of the retro games for a long time and we found nothing decent.

development_findings.summary: Final four main-game level themes undecided; Wild West is confirmed, other ideas include comic-book city, casino and an ice-cream arctic train.
A VR framebuffer effect is planned; cheap on real hardware but low-res or broken on emulators.
Performance optimisation: moving two lines saved ~100 µs; engine aggressively drops legacy features for speed (e.g., some object flags no longer supported).

context_findings.summary: Kaze and Zeina move house tomorrow; next stream will be from his new ‘dungeon’ studio after a week off, possibly with a house-tour video.
context_findings.quote: Next stream is not going to be here anymore because we are moving tomorrow… I’m going to have my own dungeon.

context_findings.summary: Kaze wants players to forget he exists so future controversies won’t spoil the game for them.
context_findings.quote: If in the future I get cancelled on Twitter, no one has to put down the game.

context_findings.summary: Excitement about YouTube growth: the ‘10 000 Triangles’ video doubled typical performance; next video covers the fast inverse square-root algorithm.
Philosophy on development speed: proud of rapid progress despite common belief that game dev is slow.
context_findings.quote: Considering how big a part this game is and how much we just got done here, doesn’t seem that much of a big deal to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze refuses overtly sexual or ‘femboy’ characters, aiming to keep tone family-friendly.
context_findings.quote: I would not want him to be referred to as a femboy, because that seems like a sexual thing.

biobak.summary: Provides redesigned star-select backgrounds, submarine model, light-cone textures and bird animations; sets many of the stream’s tasks.
Requests specific wave offsets (position and roll) for lights and offers feedback on animation speed.

zeina.summary: Appears in chat, jokes about preferring male characters and recalls traumatic ‘weeb Toad’ from Kaze’s previous hack; will shift to chat-only presence after move.

key_stories.title: Missing Sine Table Causes Submarine Chaos
key_stories.summary: While adding a gentle bob to the new submarine, Kaze saw it leap wildly because the sine function pulled garbage values. Investigation revealed math.h wasn’t included, so the compiler linked an invalid sine table. Adding the proper table restored smooth motion.
key_stories.process: Printed values, tried alternate sine, realised header missing, re-compiled.
key_stories.outcome: Sub now bobs correctly and level still runs 60 FPS.
key_stories.key_quote: How can a sine wave do that?

key_stories.title: Smoothing Lighthouse Beams
key_stories.summary: Light cones in the water course star-select looked harsh and showed an ‘X’. Kaze tweaked texture usage, blurred gradients and spaced the cones to eliminate colour banding, producing the eerie distant effect Biobak wanted.
key_stories.challenge: Banding and artifacts on light textures.
key_stories.process: Tested vertex vs prim colour, used texture whiteness as alpha, rearranged geometry.
key_stories.key_quote: You can see the colour banding even here; we need to change the circles a little bit.

key_stories.title: Giving Life to the Star-Select Bird
key_stories.summary: A new bird perches on the branch of Course 9’s star-select. Kaze imported the model, added an idle twitch and programmed a take-off when the player confirms. He discovered the engine freezes object updates during fade-out, so the bird vanishes mid-air; solving this is next on the list.
key_stories.challenge: Bird animation stops during screen fade.
key_stories.process: Integrated model, wrote code, observed freeze, identified engine limitation.
key_stories.outcome: Idle works; take-off needs engine tweak.
key_stories.key_quote: Everything just freezes when I press A; I need the bird to update.
